title: Manchester United could be in the relegation zone on Monday - so why have the fans not turned on them?
text:
You have to go back to the final throes of David Moyes’s brief reign for the last time Manchester United were given a chasing by Liverpool at Old Trafford. United fans would rather forget the particulars of that painful episode against their biggest adversaries, and will be hoping there is not a repeat, or worse, of March 16, 2014 when Jurgen Klopp’s Premier League leaders come to town on Sunday.

Yet while the 3-0 scoreline arguably flattered the home side, the enduring image for the locals that afternoon was of thousands of defiant United supporters in the lower Stretford End belting out chorus after chorus of “20 times” for the final 15 minutes of the game with their team down to ten men and being picked apart.

Moyes took it as a show of personal support but, applauding the fans as he approached the tunnel, it was notable that very few turned to cap the manager, their gaze instead fixed firmly on the south east corner of the stadium that housed the Liverpool fans. This was very much a case of keeping up appearances in front of bitter rivals and reminding them that, while they had won this particular battle, they still trailed 20-18 in the wider war of league titles won.
